learning_outcomes.description: Apply the fundamental principles of thermodynamics, units and dimensions, and the theory of fluid mechanics in practical situations in food engineering.
Apply the basics of heat and mass transfer in the use of different techniques in food processing.
Describe the concepts of phase and state transitions in foods, food freezing, interfacial phenomena in food to the structure and properties of food materials.
Evaluate separation processes, resources sustainability, control processes and instruments used in food processing.
Demonstrate problem-solving skills and critical thinking by correctly evaluating problems, performing necessary calculations, and assessing practical situations in food engineering.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment will evaluate students on their theoretical knowledge from Modules 1 to 5, covering content from both lectures and tutorials.

Exam Details:

  • The mid-term exam consists of 16 questions, including:
  • 6 to 7 open-ended questions
  • The remaining questions will be numerical exercises
  • Duration: 90 minutes
  • In-Person Attendance Required:
  • Students must attend the exam in person.
  • A UQ student ID card is required for verification.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment covers Modules 1 to 12 and evaluates students on teamwork (group of 4) and their practical understanding of key course concepts.

Assessment Details:

Students must create a poster and record an oral presentation following this structure:

  • Introduction, Experimental Setup, Main Results, Discussion, and Conclusion.
  • The assessment focuses on home-based experiments, introduced during the Week 6 tutorial.
  • Experiments will be conducted in groups of four, and the final mark will be shared equally among all group members.
  • No written report is required.

Marking criteria:

Clarity of speech (25%): This refers to how engaging the speech is - every individual should say something.

Content (30%): This refers to the understanding of the home-made experiment and the theory behind it.

Style and layout (30%): This refers to the quality of pictures, images, layout, and flow.

Critical point of view (15%): explanation of why certain events and provide reasons and solutions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final examination will assess content from Modules 6 to 12.

Exam Details:

  • The exam will be conducted on campus, and students must attend in person.
  • A UQ student ID card is required for verification.
  • The exam consists of 16 questions, including:
  • 6 to 7 open-ended questions
  • The remaining questions will be numerical exercises
  • Duration: 90 minutes.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Explanation of the following subjects: material properties, thermodynamics, mass and energy balance, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, mass transfer, psychrometry, sustainable processes, refrigeration, dehydration, and evaporation systems, sustainability, and instrument control.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
